title: Iranian beauty queen 'stranded' in Philippines fears she'll be killed if she goes home

An Iranian beauty queen who's spent two weeks in Manila airport is seeking asylum fearing she will be killed if she goes home.

Bahareh Zare Bahari, Iran's representative in the Miss InterContinental 2018 pageant, also claims the Iranian authorities are trying to silence her due to her public stand against the government.

The 31-year-old was seen holding an image of exiled Reza Pahlavi, the son of the Shah of Iran overthrown in the country's 1979 revolution and a flag of the former Iranian monarchy as props during the recent beauty contest.

(Image: Facebook)

(Image: Facebook)

Bahareh said she has been staying in the Ninoy Aquino International Airport's Terminal 3 for 12 days since she arrived from Dubai.

Speaking in the passengers' lounge, Bahareh said in a video she posted on her Facebook : "I'm really mentally sick.

"So 12 days past, I have no idea because there is no update.

"I just know I need to go out. I don't want become a refugee in the Philippines because there is no safety for me.

"I need to move to another country to have a safe place to stay. Please understand me."

(Image: Facebook)

The Philippines Immigration Department released a press release last week saying international police agency Interpol has issued a worldwide request to arrest Bahari, known as a red notice.

According to CNN , Bahareh said she was told by an immigration official that Iran had requested the notice in 2018.

She defended herself and explained what she did during the pageant was 'to try and be the voice of my people'.

She told CNN by phone that she moved to the Philippines about five years ago to study dentistry and has a student visa valid until January 2020.

(Image: Facebook)

But she was denied entry on October 17 after the trip to the Middle East.

Bahareh is currently being held on the basis of the red notice for allegedly assaulting a fellow Iranian.

Human Rights Watch deputy director Phil Robertson said in a statement that "there have been repeated incidents where rights repressing states in the Middle East have abused the (Interpol) process to try to force the return of dissidents overseas."
description: Bahareh Zare Bahari has been living in Manila airport for two weeks as she's concerned her social activism puts her at risk
